parts.text:
```xml
<output>
<analysis>
<has-cmf>The provided post does not contain a CMF number. While the absence of a CMF number is not automatically disqualifying, it suggests the post might not be directly linked to an official electoral campaign.</has-cmf>
<refers-to-candidate>The post uses the hashtag "#alegevocearatiunii" which translates to "#chooseyourvoice". While this is related to the election, it does not specifically refer to any particular candidate or party by name, surname, or any other clear identifier.  Therefore, Article 36 (7) - a does not apply.</refers-to-candidate>
<addresses-the-wide-population>The post is a paid advertisement on Facebook, a public platform.  The reach estimate is ">1M", indicating it is intended for a wide audience. Therefore, it addresses the wide population.</addresses-the-wide-population>
<electoral-objective>The hashtag "#alegevocearatiunii" ("#chooseyourvoice") encourages voters to participate in the election. However, it does not explicitly advocate for or against any specific candidate or party. The objective is not clearly to influence the vote for a particular candidate, but rather to encourage general participation.  Therefore, Article 36 (7) - c is not clearly met.</electoral-objective>
<journalism>The post's content is minimal.  It does not provide news, analysis, or opinion pieces. It's more of a generic call to action related to the election. It does not fit the criteria of journalism.</journalism>
<personal_opinion>The post does not express a personal opinion. It's a generic call to action, not a personal statement.</personal_opinion>
</analysis>

<conclusion>
<post_id>1647449636164647</post_id>
<electoral-propaganda-analysis>
The post, while related to the elections through its hashtag, lacks specific endorsements or mentions of any candidate. The call to action is general ("choose your voice"), not directed towards a specific candidate or party.  While the post is paid for and targets a large audience, the lack of explicit advocacy for a particular candidate makes it difficult to classify it definitively as electoral propaganda under Article 98 t).  The absence of a CMF number further weakens the case for it being electoral propaganda.  The "choose your voice" message could be interpreted as encouraging participation in the democratic process, rather than influencing votes for a specific candidate.
</electoral-propaganda-analysis>
<electoral-propaganda-decision>FALSE</electoral-propaganda-decision>
<electoral-propaganda-candidates/>
<responsible-party-or-group>RMDSZ/UDMR</responsible-party-or-group>
<message-for-police/>
</conclusion>
</output>
```
